body: OK, lets sum up my weird brain after I slept about it: when you run into the free space limit, the folder is stopped and you can't delete any files on that node by deleting them on other nodes. I consider this as a bug.

Has the stopped instance restarted? I'd ingenuously think it needs to sync
the index before realising that the file that caused the stop is gone. If
that index pulling isn't done because of the stopped state, a reboot
might/should work (?)

This is a bug. We need to separate the error handling more.
- We should not stop scanning because of a lack of free space. We don't need free space to scan.

Maybe:
- Should we pull but and only handle deletes when we are below the free space threshold? _Usually_ deleting files will give us more free space but this is not _always_ the case, so there should probably be an advanced option `handleDeletesWhenOutOfSpace` or something that defaults to true...

> Usually deleting files will give us more free space but this is not always the case

In case of enabled versioning deleting files won't generate more free space. :/
Yeah, and with filesystem snapshots and so on, hence usually. But that's a good point, in that we _know_ when versioning is enabled, so doing this to try up free space then would be pointless.
I'll retitle this issue to refer to the main problem, if you don't mind.

rename.from: Restart syncing when running into freespace limit
rename.to: Running into the free space limit should not prevent scanning

body: Well, maybe that wasn't the main issue that you were running into...

rename.from: Running into the free space limit should not prevent scanning
rename.to: Scanning and deletes should be processed even when above the free space limit

body: There. Even in the versioning or snapshots case, a delete/rename doesn't take up that much more space and it's worth trying.
Yeah, that is the issue. I am really bad at finding descriptive titles...

This is an important issue for me. Enough so that I might contribute a patch.

What normally happens when:
1) A large file is currently downloading from A to B
2) A deletes the file
3) B has versioning enabled?

Depending on the answer to the above situation, the same thing might happen when a folder is out of space for downloading yet a delete is allowed to propagate through.

But more importantly for me is to take folders where there is no versioning and "unstick" dozens of nodes by deleting large unneeded and perhaps partially synced files from a node that is fully synced, rather than manual intervention on a dozen individual nodes.

Perhaps a config option in the folder that says to allow deletes when the folder is otherwise in error state.

In your scenario A would send a index update saying that the file is now deleted. I don't know what exactly happens to the file being downloaded, but eventually it will be deleted.

I don't think this would need any config option, in my opinion it would always be desirable that deletions can be applied when there is too little disk space at the folder root.

I did look into the code a little bit. Seems that the insufficient space error is lumped into all "folder errors" which all cause the folder to be paused until the error is resolved.

Seems like the insufficient space condition would have to be pulled out of this group (perhaps becoming its own special status?) OR the folder management that pauses a folder on error checking if the specific error is a space issue and not pausing the folder

In either case, the pullers would want to be denied, paused, or stopped in some manner (and copiers as well?) with item level errors showing for those files. While meantime deletions can still be applied.

Additionally, the size of the file being pulled could be checked and the file denied for space constraint before pulling any of it if pulling the whole file would reduce the free space past the threshold. Not sure if this last bit is desirable behaviour or not.

Any objections to this line of thinking?

I think you may be right about not being an option at all.

It was mentioned that there are several scenarios where deletion will not be expected to actually free any space (are there cases where deletion would increase used space? I don't think there is...) However, most if not all cases where deletion doesn't free any additional space _at the time of deletion_ the files are nonetheless deleted, and thus treated as deleted files, which typically means they will age off _eventually_, and when eventually happens, more syncing can proceed.

And besides when a node is doing snapshots/archives/file versioning it really should have enough space to do so, and failing that it will remain stuck even after deletions are "applied". In this scenarrio the right thing is to get more storage space on that node.

In scenarios where the node space is rather limited and things can "accidentally" get too full, the right thing is to undo the accident (delete the file). It would be **_very_** nice to be able to resolve the whole cluster from a single point.

Separating the folder size error wouldn't be a problem, keeping scanning seems like not that much work either, but handling pulls only partially needs some thought. Having a different "modus" where only deletes are allowed in one puller iteration is one thing, but you also need to handle the scheduling of pulls (as they will never complete when free space keeps being below limit) and presentation of the error on command line and the UI. It must be apparent that the issue is with disk space, as opposed to e.g. missing peer device. And there will probably be corner cases that didn't come up yet.

@vontrapp If reflinks are involved (as is possible on XFS, BTRFS, or OCFS2 on Linux, or when using deduplication on ZFS), then there's no guarantee that deleting a file will _ever_ free space, as all the (filesystem-level) blocks in the file may be reflinked by other files on the volume.  However, I don't think Syncthing should care about that (since it's not hugely likely, and there is no sane way to care about it), and agree that it should still process deletions and scanning instead of pausing the folder.

@imsodin For the UI part, perhaps turn the folder name yellow to indicate soft-failures like this that don't prevent the folder from being paused?  I can think of a couple of other situations that might be handled similarly if partial pulls were possible (for example, getting an index update telling you to update a file that you don't have permission to access).

I think there may a misconception about the folder stopped state: It isn't really stopped, if the error goes away, it will recover by itself. It's just that by checking folder health before pulling and subsequently deleting we prevent this particular error from going away by remote action. So in my opinion there doesn't need to be an additional state, that would be unnecessary increased UI complexity, it should just give the appropriate reason for the error state in the expanded folder pane. The way I see this issue, it is less about a change of sync behaviour but about keeping as much operations up and running as long as possible (thus allowing certain scenarios to get unstuck where today they keep stuck until manual intervention).

@imsodin You're right, I did misunderstand this a bit.  I was under the impression that the 'Stopped' state was functionally equivalent to 'Paused', as I've never seen it recover by itself when I fix the issue that stopped it (it's also been a while since I ran into such an issue, and I've been in the habit of forcing a rescan after fixing the issue though).

Given that, I would tend to agree with your assessment.

So there are already per file error states. Examples are:
"file went away on remote server while syncing"
"remote server that has file went away"
"symlinks not supported"

Errors like these show up under an error count link under the folder. Expanding the link lists each file in error state and an explanation of the error (with strings like the above)

Folder state is to be stuck at a certain percentage of sync and not progressing, along with this file error count.

Is this the direction we want to go with free space errors? That is the file puller generates an error for that file that says it can't (or refuses to) pull the file for lack of space. And the folder remains out of sync, with explanations, but doesn't have a folder health level error?
